item.title: Is the future of trucking a better truck?
item.description: Technology can make big rigs more comfortable and easier to drive. But will new tech improve drivers' jobs, or eliminate them?

item.title: Judge sides with Meta in antitrust trial, will not spin off WhatsApp and Instagram
item.description: A federal judge ruled against the Federal Trade Commission's antitrust suit alleging that Meta had stifled competition by buying up its rivals.

item.title: Report finds some AI-enabled toys shared inappropriate content or collected data
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Teresa Murray, the co-author of a new report on the potential dangers of artificial intelligence-enabled children's toys.

item.title: Hackers are helping hijackers steal cargo shipments in real life, researchers find
item.description: Researchers say hackers are using their tech skills to help criminals hijack cargo shipments in real life.

item.title: DIY Disney? The company is exploring AI so fans can make content from Disney stories
item.description: Disney CEO Bob Iger said his company is talking with AI companies about allowing subscribers to create their own short-form videos on Disney+.

item.title: Google launches a lawsuit targeting text message scammers
item.description: Ever gotten a text saying you forgot to pay a nonexistent road toll or need to pick up a mystery package? Google's going after the scammers behind those messages.

item.title: Inside the unofficial movement to save the em dash — from A.I.
item.description: The extra-long hyphen known as the em dash is common in AI-generated text. While some writers have responded by choosing to avoid the punctuation mark, others are fighting back.

item.title: A look at the latest effort to get more Americans in rural communities online
item.description: A good portion of rural America still needs access to fast internet. Some worry that new directives that call for using less expensive broadband technology will make internet service less reliable.

item.title: Immigration agents have new technology to identify and track people
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security is adopting powerful new tools to monitor noncitizens. Privacy advocates are worried they erode privacy rights for all Americans.

item.title: Recruiting companies are starting to hold job interviews using AI
item.description: Companies have begun using AI to interview potential employees, and a new study shows a number of job candidates may prefer being interviewed by AI.
